reference.shortdesc: An index-see element within an indexterm element redirects the reader to another index entry that the reader should reference instead of the current one.

section.title: Usage information
section.p: The index-see and index-see-also elements allow a form of redirection to another index entry within the generated index. The index-see element refers to an index entry that the reader should use instead of the current one, whereas the index-see-also element refers to an index entry that the reader should use in addition to the current one.
There can be multiple index-see elements for a single index entry.

section.title: Processing expectations
section.p: Processors should ignore index-see and index-see-also elements if their parent indexterm element contains any indexterm children.

Because an index-see indicates a redirection to use instead of the current entry, it is an error if, for any index-see, there is also an index-see-also or an indexterm for the same index entry (that is, another entry with an identical sort key). For example, if an indexterm element with the content "Memory stick" also includes <index-see>USB drive</index-see>, it is an error if there is also an indexterm with the contents "Memory stick". This is to prevent index entries that are both a redirect and a page reference, such as:
An implementation MAY give an error message when it encounters this condition, and MAY recover from this error condition by treating the index-see as an index-see-also.

section.title: Specialization hierarchy
section.p: The index-see element is specialized from index-base. It is defined in the indexing domain module.

section.title: Attributes
section.p: The following attributes are available on this element: and keyref.
